instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.A1708: What is A1708? A1708 is a model number for a 13 inch size MacBook Pro Retina from years Mid 2017, 2016 with EMC 3164, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-00840, 820-00875..
definitions.820-00875: What is 820-00875? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPVOUT_S0_LCDBKLT: What is PPVOUT_S0_LCDBKLT? PPVOUT_S0_LCDBKLT is a power rail that powers the LED light in the screen of the device that allows you to see what is on the screen. When this is low or missing, the screen will be dim..
definitions.USBC_XB_CC1: What is USBC_XB_CC1? USBC_XB_CC1 is a line between the USB-C muxing chip such as the CD3217 or CD3215 and the USB-C charger. Communication must happen on this line in order for the USB-C charger to put out 20v..
definitions.USBC_XB_CC2: What is USBC_XB_CC2? USBC_XB_CC2 is a line between the USB-C muxing chip such as the CD3217 or CD3215 and the USB-C charger. Communication must happen on this line in order for the USB-C charger to put out 20v..
definitions.PP20V_USBC_XB_VBUS: What is PP20V_USBC_XB_VBUS? PP20V_USBC_XB_VBUS is 20v in from the USB-C charger on USB-C powered Macbook Pros..

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00875</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power
threads.message:
Hi,

I have an <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00875</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A with that has no power.
It had no backlight and <SIGNAL>PPVOUT_S0_LCDBKLT</SIGNAL> was shorted, and i replaced <CAPACITOR>C8467</CAPACITOR> and <CAPACITOR>C8463</CAPACITOR> because they were burnt.
After replacing those, the mac didn't power on again. It only pulls 5V from ampmeter.

I notice that one of the charging port was rebooting, and when measured, on <CHIP>U3200</CHIP> (the on that was rebooting), I get, on diode mode, 0V on <SIGNAL>USBC_XB_CC1</SIGNAL> and on <SIGNAL>USBC_XB_CC2</SIGNAL>.

After replacing <CHIP>U3200</CHIP>, CC1/2 gets 0.600V on diode reading, but still no power, and a black ampmeter on that port.

<SIGNAL>PP20V_USBC_XB_VBUS_F</SIGNAL> has 0V on diode reading and 0.13 ohm to ground but because it is a high voltage line, i'm not sure if those readings are ok.

F3010 seams to be ok.

Can you help?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00875</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power
threads.message:
"<SIGNAL>PP20V_USBC_XB_VBUS_F</SIGNAL> has 0V on diode reading and 0.13 ohm"
Post something like "0.xxx" WITHOUT any final "V" for diode mode.
0.13 ohm means pure short; unless you mean 0.13x in kohm scale.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00875</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power
threads.message:
Tks for the reply. I'll try to remember that.

<SIGNAL>PP20V_USBC_XB_VBUS_F</SIGNAL> readings on diode mode are 0.0003, and 0.13 ohm on resistance to ground.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00875</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power
threads.message:
So have a short there.
If the short is on pin 2 of F3010, then bad <CHIP>U3200</CHIP>.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00875</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power
threads.message:
The short seams to be on pin 1 (<SIGNAL>PP20V_USBC_XB_VBUS</SIGNAL>).
Pin 2 has 1.787 on diode readings.

I thing that it's safe to inject some voltage on that line. Is it?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00875</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power
threads.message: <DIODE>D3400</DIODE> should be the culprit there; probably died because of fake charger.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00875</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power
threads.message:
Hi,
After lifting <DIODE>D3400</DIODE> the sort remained, and so I replaced the <CHIP>U3200</CHIP>. It was a bad <CHIP>U3200</CHIP>.
TKS!
